results.title: Making sense (TEFC) [Colour]
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, Eurfron Gwynne Jones and Francis Fuchs
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Children Growing Up”.
A new born baby has all the five senses needed to perceive his outside world, but making something of it is a slow developmental process. This program constructs situations and experiments to demonstrate how a child sees and makes sense of the world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: British Broadcasting Corporation, Eurfron Gwynne Jones and Francis Fuchs

results.title: Making pottery. No. 1
results.creator_credit: Hartvig Jensen Film Productions and Harvig Jensen
results.brief_description: Shows how raw clay is processed in preparation for modelling. Demonstrations show a jug and a flower pot being made; creative use of engraving and decorating; the final firing and glazing processes.

results.title: Making perfect babies
results.creator_credit: Cinefort, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, ONF | NFB, Telefilms Canada, Mary Armstrong and Gwynne Basen
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “On the eighth day: perfecting Mother Nature”.
The day a baby can be genetically made-to-measure is still far away, but it is rapidly moving from the realm of fantasy to that of probability. “Making perfect babies” offers a critical examination of the genetic technology and its potential applications and raises important questions about why the technology is being developed and how it may affect the lives of women and society as a whole. Includes interviews with scientist and feminist Ruth Hubbard and disability activist Marsha Saxton.

results.title: Making open hearth steel
results.creator_credit: Merton Park, British Iron and Steel Federation, Frank A. Hoare and John Durst
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Open hearth furnace series”.
Chemical reactions by which steel is refined from iron and steel scrap are explained by animated sequences. The function of slag and the differences between acid and basic furnaces are also outlined.

results.title: Making of the soil
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit and J.V. Durden
results.brief_description: This instructional film for farmers and agricultural students, tells of the formation and fertility of the soil, the variety of soils in Britain, and stresses the need for their preservation. By a knowledge of the origin of soil and understanding of its needs, we can preserve and improve its fertility.

results.title: Making of Bush Mechanics
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.
results.description:
Australia’s First Peoples are connected to Country through thousands of generations of kinship ties. We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.
description_for_label:

We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.

results.title: Making of a legend: Gone with the wind
results.creator_credit: Turner Entertainment, Selznick Properties, L. Jeffrey Selznick and David Hinton
results.brief_description: A feature length documentary which takes a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the 1939 feature film “Gone With the Wind”. Utilises some rare film footage including several screen tests for the part of Scarlett O’Hara, and home movies featuring Vivien Leigh. A fascinating inside view of one of the great accomplishments in motion picture history. Narrated by Christopher Plummer.

results.title: Making multicultural Australia: a multimedia documentary (PC & MAC)
results.creator_credit: New South Wales. Board of Studies. Interactive Design Group
results.brief_description: Multiculturalism can mean many different things - these CD-ROMs allow you to explore many ideas and hear people from many different perscpectives putting their points of view. View a documenatry, take part in a debate, see a festival of multicultural arts, explore the “Harvest of Endurance” history scroll and read more than 2,500 pages of printable reports, documents and newspaper articles.

results.title: Making movies
results.brief_description: This is a compilation of documentary and archival footage, newsreels, motion picture trailers and excerpts on the subject of making movies. It includes behind the scenes look at Psycho, Dr Zhivago and The Godfather with excerpts from Hollywood classics such as The Ten Commandments, Ben Hur, Jason and the Argonauts, The Jazz singer and many more. The program is broken into segments dealing with all aspects of motion picture production and the motion picture industry (not necessarily in the following order): The screen director (Alfred Hitchcock, David Lean); Let’s go to the movies (history of Hollywood and motion pictures); Prince of Terror (Christopher Lee and vampire/horror films); Movies are adventure (action/adventure films); History brought to life (historical films and re-enactments); Monsters and special effects; The screen writer (Mario Puzo); Screen actors (Elizabeth Taylor, Richard Burton); The costume designer (Judy Garland in costume test); The art director; The cinematographer; The sound man; Moments in music (Danny Kaye, Bing Crosby, Mario Lanza). Contains some very amusing and rare footage and is interesting and informative from a historical point of view. NB: The segments are disjointed and the quality variable.

results.title: Making Mortise and Tenon Joints
results.brief_description: Demonstrates three different techniques for making three variations on the mortise-tenon joint. Explains how to organise procedures for maximum efficiency and how to work with common hand tools and machines found in most shops.
